articles.headline: U.S. Ending Oil-Royalty Program After Scandal
articles.snippet: Federal employees had engaged in corruption and sexual misconduct with industry officials, a report said.
articles.abstract: Federal employees had engaged in corruption and sexual misconduct with industry officials, a report said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Interior Department announced on Wednesday that it was ending an oil and gas royalty program that ignited a scandal last year when it was disclosed that federal employees had engaged in corruption, drug use and sexual misconduct with oil industry officials.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Tuning In a Zippier Zune
articles.snippet: Despite new features, Microsoft’s Zune music/video player may still play second fiddle to the iPod.
articles.abstract: Despite new features, Microsoft’s Zune music/video player may still play second fiddle to the iPod.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the years, mention of the word “Microsoft” has set off a variety of emotions. Some consider how Microsoft achieved its success, and feel anger. Some consider how Microsoft borrows other companies’ ideas, and feel indignation. Some consider recent battles with Windows, and feel frustration.

articles.headline: Fight Grows Over Labels on Household Cleaners
articles.snippet: Companies struggle to look environmentally friendly while keeping their “secret sauces” away from competitors.
articles.abstract: Companies struggle to look environmentally friendly while keeping their “secret sauces” away from competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Procter & Gamble, the maker of Mr. Clean, is under pressure to come clean itself.

articles.headline: Taking a Chance on Risk, Again
articles.snippet: Now that the crisis has subsided — knock on wood — it’s important to avoid an overly simplistic view of risk and the financial system.
articles.abstract: Now that the crisis has subsided — knock on wood — it’s important to avoid an overly simplistic view of risk and the financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is there more or less risk on Wall Street today?

articles.headline: Hedge Funds Challenged Over Fees
articles.snippet: After a rough 2008, clients have grown tired of the fee formula that hedge funds use to make money.
articles.abstract: After a rough 2008, clients have grown tired of the fee formula that hedge funds use to make money.
articles.lead_paragraph: “TWO and twenty”  three words that long held the key to transforming fledgling hedge fund managers into instant tycoons  may be due for a pruning.

articles.headline: Cuomo Is Said to Issue Subpoenas in Merrill Case
articles.snippet: Andrew M. Cuomo wants to know if Bank of America directors were misled or “little more than rubber stamps” for management.
articles.abstract: Andrew M. Cuomo wants to know if Bank of America directors were misled or “little more than rubber stamps” for management.
articles.lead_paragraph: Capping a week of scrutiny for Bank of America, New York Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo took another swing on Wednesday at uncovering which of the bank’s executives knew about large losses and bonus payouts at Merrill Lynch just before the two banks merged last year.

articles.headline: Proposed Tax on Sugary Beverages Debated
articles.snippet: The proposed tax is billed as a way to fight obesity and provide billions for health care reform.
articles.abstract: The proposed tax is billed as a way to fight obesity and provide billions for health care reform.
articles.lead_paragraph: The debate over a tax on sugary soft drinks  billed as a way to fight obesity and provide billions for health care reform  is starting to fizz over.

articles.headline: In Somalia, a Leader Is Raising Hopes for Stability
articles.snippet: Analysts say President Sheik Sharif Sheik Ahmed offers hope for stability, but he needs to act against militants.
articles.abstract: Analysts say President Sheik Sharif Sheik Ahmed offers hope for stability, but he needs to act against militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia  From the gates of Villa Somalia, the hilltop presidential palace, this ruin of a city almost looks peaceful.

articles.headline: As Race Debate Grows, Obama Steers Clear of It
articles.snippet: Beyond posing a distraction, the race issue could further strain the president’s broad but tenuous coalition.
articles.abstract: Beyond posing a distraction, the race issue could further strain the president’s broad but tenuous coalition.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama has long suggested that he would like to move beyond race. The question now is whether the country will let him.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Citing Risks, U.S. Seeks New Rules for Niche Banks
articles.snippet: The Obama administration wants Federal Reserve oversight, but the banks say their survival is at stake.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration wants Federal Reserve oversight, but the banks say their survival is at stake.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY  Generations ago, industrialists and financiers extracted fortunes from the copper and gold mines dug into the canyons near here. Now, their modern-day counterparts are resisting a government proposal that could shut down what has become another gold mine of sorts.

articles.headline: White House Scraps Bush’s Approach to Missile Shield
articles.snippet: President Obama on Thursday announced a reconfigured system that won’t be based in Poland or the Czech Republic, and will be aimed at intercepting Iranian missiles.
articles.abstract: President Obama on Thursday announced a reconfigured system that won’t be based in Poland or the Czech Republic, and will be aimed at intercepting Iranian missiles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama scrapped his predecessor’s proposed antiballistic missile shield in Eastern Europe on Thursday and ordered instead the development of a reconfigured system designed to shoot down short- and medium-range Iranian missiles.
